Package mz

Class StableQuick

java.lang.Object
mz.SortComparable
mz.Quick
mz.StableQuick
All Implemented Interfaces:
QuickInterface<Comparable>, Sort<Comparable>, SortSwap<Comparable>
Direct Known Subclasses:
IntroStableQuick
public class StableQuick extends Quick
Stable QuickSort is an extension of the QuickSort algorithm that aims to preserve the relative order of elements with equal values during the sorting process. In a standard QuickSort algorithm, the order of equal elements may change, making it an unstable sorting algorithm. Stable QuickSort addresses this limitation by introducing additional steps to maintain stability.
Since:
1.0

  • Constructor Details

    • StableQuick

      public StableQuick()
      Stable Quick Sort:
      Is an extension of the QuickSort algorithm that aims to preserve the relative order of elements with equal values during the sorting process. In a standard QuickSort algorithm, the order of equal elements may change, making it an unstable sorting algorithm. Stable QuickSort addresses this limitation by introducing additional steps to maintain stability.

      Example:
      1. Select a pivot element: The first step is to choose a pivot element from the array. The pivot can be selected in various ways, such as picking the first, last, or middle element.
      2. Partitioning: The array is partitioned into two subarrays based on the pivot element. One subarray contains elements smaller than the pivot, while the other subarray contains elements greater than the pivot. The partitioning step ensures that the pivot element is in its final sorted position.
      3. Recursion: Recursively apply Stable QuickSort to the two subarrays created in the previous step. This step involves selecting a new pivot element for each subarray and performing partitioning until the subarrays reach a size of 1 or 0, as these subarrays are considered already sorted.
      4. Concatenation: Once the recursion is complete, the sorted subarrays are concatenated to obtain the final sorted array. The order of concatenation is crucial to maintaining stability. The elements from the left subarray, which are smaller or equal to the pivot, should appear before the elements from the right subarray, which are greater than the pivot.
      Note:
      By carefully handling the partitioning and concatenation steps, Stable QuickSort ensures that elements with equal values remain in their original relative order after sorting. This makes it a stable sorting algorithm.

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(log(n))
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQStableQuick
      • IntroStableQuick

    • stableQuickInc

      protected void stableQuickInc(Comparable[] array)
      stableQuickInc that performs an in-place sorting of a Comparable array using a stable version of the QuickSort algorithm.
      • The original array is converted into an ArrayList by creating a new ArrayList and passing the array as an argument to the ArrayList constructor: new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(array)).
      • The ArrayList is then passed as an argument to the stableRecursiveInc method, which performs a stable sorting of the ArrayList and returns a sorted list.
      • The sorted list obtained from stableRecursiveInc is converted back into an array using the toArray() method with an empty Comparable array as the argument: list.toArray(new Comparable[0]).
      • The sorted elements are copied from the sorted list back into the original array using System.arraycopy(). The elements are copied starting from the beginning of the original array index 0, and the number of elements copied is equal to the length of the array: array.length.
      stableQuickInc method uses the stableRecursiveInc method to sort the original array in a stable manner by converting it into an ArrayList. After obtaining the sorted list, the sorted elements are copied back into the original array. This allows the QuickSort algorithm to maintain stability by using the stableRecursiveInc method instead of the standard partitioning logic in QuickSort.
      Parameters:
      array - The original array containing Comparable elements.
      See Also:
      • stableRecursiveInc(List)

    • stableQuickDec

      protected void stableQuickDec(Comparable[] array)

      • The sorted list obtained from stableRecursiveDec is converted back into an array using the toArray() method with an empty Comparable array as the argument: list.toArray(new Comparable[0]).
      • The sorted elements are copied from the sorted list back into the original array using System.arraycopy(). The elements are copied starting from the beginning of the original array index 0, and the number of elements copied is equal to the length of the array: array.length.

    • stableQuickInc

      protected void stableQuickInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int right)
      stableQuickInc that performs an in-place sorting of a subarray within a Comparable array using a stable version of the QuickSort algorithm.
      • The method creates a new array called newArray with a size equal to the length of the subarray to be sorted (right - left). This new array will be used to create a temporary list for sorting.
      • The elements from the original array that correspond to the subarray to be sorted are copied into the newArray using the System.arraycopy() method.
      • The "newArray" is converted into an ArrayList using Arrays.asList() and then passed as an argument to the stableRecursiveInc method. This method, as you previously provided, performs a stable sorting of the ArrayList and returns a sorted list.
      • The sorted list obtained from "stableRecursiveInc" is converted back into an array using the toArray() method with an empty Comparable array as the argument.
      • The sorted elements are copied from the sorted list back into the original array using System.arraycopy(). The elements are copied starting from the left index of the original array, and the number of elements copied is equal to the size of the sorted list.
      stableQuickInc method uses the stableRecursiveInc method to sort a subarray of the original array in a stable manner by creating a temporary array and converting it into an ArrayList. After obtaining the sorted list, the sorted elements are copied back into the original array. This allows the QuickSort algorithm to maintain stability by using the stableRecursiveInc method instead of the standard partitioning logic in QuickSort.
      Parameters:
      array - The original array containing Comparable elements.
      left - The index representing the left boundary of the subarray to be sorted.
      right - The index representing the right boundary of the subarray to be sorted.
      See Also:
      • stableRecursiveInc(List)

      • The sorted list obtained from "stableRecursiveDec" is converted back into an array using the toArray() method with an empty Comparable array as the argument.
      • The sorted elements are copied from the sorted list back into the original array using System.arraycopy(). The elements are copied starting from the left index of the original array, and the number of elements copied is equal to the size of the sorted list.

      See Also:

    • stableRecursiveInc

      protected List<Comparable> stableRecursiveInc(List<Comparable> list)
      stableRecursiveInc implements a recursive sorting algorithm called stableRecursiveInc that sorts a list of Comparable elements in ascending order. The algorithm uses the concept of a pivot element and divides the list into two parts: smaller elements and greater elements, relative to the pivot.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method takes a list as input and checks if the size of the list is less than or equal to 1. If so, it returns the list as it is already sorted (base case of the recursion).
      • If the list has more than one element, it proceeds to find the pivot element. The pivot is the element at the middle index of the list.
      • The algorithm creates two empty lists, smaller and greater, to hold the elements smaller and greater than the pivot, respectively.
      • It iterates through the original list and compares each element to the pivot.
        • If the element is smaller than the pivot, it adds it to the smaller list.
        • If the element is greater than the pivot, it adds it to the greater list.
        • If the element is equal to the pivot, it determines its relative position to the pivot index and adds it to either the smaller or greater list accordingly.
      • After the iteration, the algorithm recursively calls itself with the smaller list and the greater list, separately.
      • The results of the recursive calls are stored in two lists, sa1 and sa2.
      • The algorithm creates a new list, "ans", and populates it by adding all the elements from sa1, followed by the pivot element, and finally, all the elements from sa2.
      stableRecursiveInc the algorithm uses the divide-and-conquer approach by recursively sorting smaller sublists and combining them to produce the final sorted list. The use of the pivot element helps in dividing the list into smaller parts, which allows the algorithm to achieve an efficient sorting result.
      Parameters:
      list - sorts a list of Comparable elements in ascending order.
      Returns:
      The sorted list, is returned.

    • stableRecursiveDec

      protected List<Comparable> stableRecursiveDec(List<Comparable> list)
      stableRecursiveDec implements a recursive sorting algorithm called stableRecursiveDec that sorts a list of Comparable elements in descending order. The algorithm uses the concept of a pivot element and divides the list into two parts: smaller elements and greater elements, relative to the pivot.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method takes a list as input and checks if the size of the list is less than or equal to 1. If so, it returns the list as it is already sorted (base case of the recursion).
      • If the list has more than one element, it proceeds to find the pivot element. The pivot is the element at the middle index of the list.
      • The algorithm creates two empty lists, smaller and greater, to hold the elements smaller and greater than the pivot, respectively.
      • It iterates through the original list and compares each element to the pivot.
        • If the element is greater than the pivot, it adds it to the smaller list.
        • If the element is smaller than the pivot, it adds it to the greater list.
        • If the element is equal to the pivot, it determines its relative position to the pivot index and adds it to either the smaller or greater list accordingly.
      • After the iteration, the algorithm recursively calls itself with the smaller list and the greater list, separately.
      • The results of the recursive calls are stored in two lists, sa1 and sa2.
      • The algorithm creates a new list, "ans", and populates it by adding all the elements from sa1, followed by the pivot element, and finally, all the elements from sa2.
      stableRecursiveDec the algorithm uses the divide-and-conquer approach by recursively sorting smaller sublists and combining them to produce the final sorted list. The use of the pivot element helps in dividing the list into smaller parts, which allows the algorithm to achieve an efficient sorting result.
      Parameters:
      list - sorts a list of Comparable elements in descending order.
      Returns:
      The sorted list, is returned.
